newsitem.title: ROMANIA: ROMANIA SEES LOWER 1997 INFLATION AT 20 PCT.
newsitem.headline: ROMANIA SEES LOWER 1997 INFLATION AT 20 PCT.

text.p: Romania expects 12-month inflation to slip to 20 percent in 1997 from around 30 percent this year, the National Forecasting Board (CNP) said on Monday.
"We expect a price index of 120 percent for the December 1996-December 1997 period," CNP's Petrica Grama said.

Romania expects inflation of about 30 percent this year, a target recently revised from a previous 20 percent, but local economists say the 12-month figure will be higher due to hefty rises in energy and fuel prices in July.

In July, electricity and thermal power prices rose by 58 percent and fuel prices by approximately 30 percent sending year-on-year inflation up to 40.3 percent from 33.8 percent in June. August's 12-month inflation was 44.2 percent.

Romania has made progress in cutting inflation from the near-hyperinflation of the immediate post-communist years. Inflation fell to 27.8 percent last year from 61.7 in 1994 and almost 300 percent in 1993. -- Luli Popescu, Bucharest Newsroom 40-1 3120264
